Award.AwardTitle: Nanoconfinement and its Influence on Polymerization

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this grant is to elucidate the fundamental mechanism that is responsible for changes in step-growth and free-radical polymerizations under nanoconfinement. Nanoporous matrices will be used as model confinement geometries and work will be carried out in both cylindrical and spherical confinement regimes and with various surface chemistries. Calorimetric and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) studies will be performed to determine reaction rates and limiting conversions and will be augmented by studies of nanoconfined liquid dynamics and structure using optical Keer effect (OKE) spectroscopy. The investigation will quantify the importance of confinement-induced changes in liquid structure and liquid dynamics on reactivity and thermodynamics in confined polymerizations.

The results of the proposed study are important for controlling polymer synthesis at the nanoscale in nanocomposite, nanolithographic, and nanoelectronic applications. The proposed effort will also provide excellent state-of-the-art research training for the undergraduate and graduate students involved, and strong efforts will be made to include under-represented minorities. Outreach efforts will include involvement of high-school students in summer research, as well as participation in two successful outreach programs coordinated by the TTU Institute for the Development and Enrichment of Advanced Learners (IDEAL), "Super Saturdays," a science-enrichment program for fourth- to six-graders and "Science - It's a Girl Thing" (SIGT) aimed at promoting interest in science and engineering for junior high and high school girls.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project deals with the fundamental mechanisms responsible for changes in polymerizations under nanoconfinement, including changes in reaction kinetics, thermodynamics, and the final polymer product properties.  In particular, the molecular weight and isotacticity for poly(methyl methacrylate) increase for synthesis under confinement in 13nm-diameter nanopores, with more dramatic changes for hydrophilic native pores.  The glass transition temperature also increases for both hydrophobic and hydrophilic pore surfaces compared with the bulk, but again the increase in hydrophilic pores is more pronounced. In addition, nanoconfinement decreases the ceiling temperature.  The explanation for these results lies in the decrease in the diffusivity and entropy of confined chains, coupled with a reaction that appears to take place at the pore surface due to specific interactions with the hydroxyl groups at the pore wall.  The latter effect is related to the structure and dynamics of the monomer under nanoconfinement, and this was further probed using an ultrafast laser technique known as optical Kerr effect spectroscopy which is able to interrogate the picosecond rotational dynamics of monomers in the bulk liquid and nanoconfined liquid.  As part of this work, fabrication of optical quality nanoporous silica sol-gel glasses with well-defined pore sizes was also carried out.  The results indicate that  the reorientational dynamics of nanoconfined methyl methacrylate and 4-cumyl phenol cyanate ester monomers are well described by a two-state model corresponding a subensemble of surface and core bulk-like molecules.

The knoweldge gained from the research will facilitate controlling polymer synthesis at the nanoscale in nanocomposite, nanolithographic, and nanoelectronic applications.  The results further indicate that nanoconfinement could be used as a potential synthetic tool for controlling properties of polymers. Six graduate students were trained in the course of the work, and outreach efforts included participation in two successful programs coordinated by the TTU Institute for the Development and Enrichment of Advanced Learners (IDEAL), "Super Saturdays," a science-enrichment program for fourth- to six-graders and "Science – It's a Girl Thing" (SIGT) aimed at promoting interest in science and engineering for junior high and high school girls.


 


Last Modified: 11/30/2016
Modified by: Sindee L Simon
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The project deals with the fundamental mechanisms responsible for changes in polymerizations under nanoconfinement, including changes in reaction kinetics, thermodynamics, and the final polymer product properties. In particular, the molecular weight and isotacticity for poly(methyl methacrylate) increase for synthesis under confinement in 13nm-diameter nanopores, with more dramatic changes for hydrophilic native pores. The glass transition temperature also increases for both hydrophobic and hydrophilic pore surfaces compared with the bulk, but again the increase in hydrophilic pores is more pronounced. In addition, nanoconfinement decreases the ceiling temperature. The explanation for these results lies in the decrease in the diffusivity and entropy of confined chains, coupled with a reaction that appears to take place at the pore surface due to specific interactions with the hydroxyl groups at the pore wall. The latter effect is related to the structure and dynamics of the monomer under nanoconfinement, and this was further probed using an ultrafast laser technique known as optical Kerr effect spectroscopy which is able to interrogate the picosecond rotational dynamics of monomers in the bulk liquid and nanoconfined liquid. As part of this work, fabrication of optical quality nanoporous silica sol-gel glasses with well-defined pore sizes was also carried out. The results indicate that the reorientational dynamics of nanoconfined methyl methacrylate and 4-cumyl phenol cyanate ester monomers are well described by a two-state model corresponding a subensemble of surface and core bulk-like molecules. The knoweldge gained from the research will facilitate controlling polymer synthesis at the nanoscale in nanocomposite, nanolithographic, and nanoelectronic applications. The results further indicate that nanoconfinement could be used as a potential synthetic tool for controlling properties of polymers. Six graduate students were trained in the course of the work, and outreach efforts included participation in two successful programs coordinated by the TTU Institute for the Development and Enrichment of Advanced Learners (IDEAL), "Super Saturdays," a science-enrichment program for fourth- to six-graders and "Science – It's a Girl Thing" (SIGT) aimed at promoting interest in science and engineering for junior high and high school girls.
